newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Canberra plans new Hindmarsh bridge inquiry.
newsitem.headline: Canberra plans new Hindmarsh bridge inquiry.

text.p: The Australian government will have to hold a fifth inquiry into the the proposed Hindmarsh Island Bridge in South Australia, a spokeswoman for Aboriginal Affairs Minister John Herron said on Tuesday.
The Senate on Monday rejected a government bill that would have authorised construction of the bridge, which is opposed by local aboriginal groups arguing it would disturb their cultural heritage.
"We will be forced to have another inquiry," the spokeswoman said.
The bill came close to passing on Monday but was thwarted by tactical voting in the Senate by minor parties.

The Labor opposition aimed to back the bill in an amended form to protect Aboriginal interests but, according to one Senate source, was surprised when Greens senators helped the government vote down the proposed changes.
That left Labor with only the unamended bill to vote on. The party chose to vote against it.
One of the four previous inquiries into the bridge rejected a claim that the site was important to cultural secrets held by Aboriginal women.
The claim that there were such secrets -- which, being secret, could not be revealed -- had been fabricated, the earlier inquiry found.
